item.title: A Second Wave of Popular Anger Is Building in Iran
item.description: The heavy-handed response to protests has deepened people’s hatred of the regime, and Iranians are speaking out.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Faucon

item.title: Takaichi’s Long Trip From Heavy-Metal Drummer to Japan’s Political Heavyweight
item.description: The conservative prime minister bet her seat in a snap election Sunday she hopes will cement her power—and move Japan closer to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Junko Fukutome

item.title: Trump Calls for New Nuclear Pact With Russia as Previous Treaty Ends
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said future arms constraints should include China.
item.dc:creator: Michael R. Gordon

item.title: Argentina Inflation Battle Jolts Confidence in Milei’s Overhaul
item.description: The resignation of Argentina’s statistics chief over delays in updating the inflation index has stirred up memories of price meddling.
item.dc:creator: Silvina Frydlewsky

item.title: Opinion | The ‘Iranian Lobby’ and the Rights Watch
item.description: Uncomfortable Middle Eastern questions for two American NGOs.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | The Name ‘West Bank’ Erases the Truth
item.description: ‘Judea’ and ‘Samaria’ are faithful to history, as U.S. lawmakers increasingly realize.
item.dc:creator: Gideon Israel

item.title: Bank of Canada Gov. Macklem Warns of Misdiagnosing Economic Weakness
item.description: Central banker says rate cuts aimed at lifting economy adapting to U.S. trade friction, technological advances might backfire.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Trump Softens Criticism of U.K. Deal Ceding Control of Indian Ocean Island
item.description: The comments came as the British government has moved forward with a deal to cede sovereignty of Diego Garcia to Mauritius.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Weisgerber

item.title: Three Takeaways From the Ukraine Peace Talks
item.description: The negotiations have so far struggled to resolve central questions on territory, but prisoner exchanges are progressing.
item.dc:creator: Anastasiia Malenko

item.title: Cuba Says It Is Ready to Engage With Trump as Fuel Shortages Worsen
item.description: President Miguel Díaz-Canel is grappling with an economic implosion and says he is willing to talk to the U.S. government as equals.
item.dc:creator: José de Córdoba

item.title: Opinion | The EU’s Secret Assault on Your Free Speech
item.description: A decision against X looks technical on the surface but is a road map for future censorship.
item.dc:creator: Megan K. Jacobson

item.title: German Factory Orders Unexpectedly Soar as Industrial Rebound Gathers Pace
item.description: Orders climbed 7.8% on month in December, accelerating from November’s rise, a sign that the recent struggles of the country’s industrial sector might be easing.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Opinion | Trump Takes the Path of Least Resistance in Venezuela
item.description: He seems to want a client state; democracy isn’t his priority.

item.title: Opinion | Disarm Hamas or Unleash Hell Trying
item.description: The terrorists losing their last hostage is win for Trump, but there’s a necessary next step.

item.title: U.K. Long-Term Borrowing Costs Climb, Sterling Falls as Political Uncertainty Grows
item.description: Pressure has built on U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer over his appointment of former British ambassador to Washington Peter Mandelson.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Mukuru

item.title: Epstein Fallout Piles Pressure on U.K. Prime Minister
item.description: Keir Starmer—already trailing in the polls —faces questions over his decision to appoint an old Epstein friend as ambassador to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: TSMC to Make More-Advanced Chips in Japan as Part of AI Push
item.description: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing’s 3-nanometer technology represents a major leap for Japan, which doesn’t have capacity to mass produce advanced chips essential for artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Sherry Qin

item.title: The $100 Billion Bet on Venezuelan Oil Relies on a Broken State Company
item.description: Foreign energy companies are facing a legal minefield dealing with PdVSA, which has long been accused of corruption.

item.title: A Wargame Shows Just How Vulnerable Europe Is to a Russian Attack
item.description: With America disengaging, Russia might be ready for a new war much sooner than previously estimated.

item.title: Why Big Tech Is Throwing Cash Into India in Quest for AI Supremacy
item.description: Lured by its big, tech-savvy population, Google and other giants are sinking tens of billions into the Indian market.
item.dc:creator: Rory Jones

item.title: The American and Chinese Economies Are Hurtling Toward a Messy Divorce
item.description: The breakup is focused on sensitive matters now considered national-security issues, including semiconductors, food and energy.

item.title: Top Democrat Launches Probe Into ‘Spy Sheikh’ Deal With Trump Company
item.description: World Liberty Financial said lawmakers are “harassing a private American business to score political points.”

item.description: A Takaichi win would send Beijing a message but not fix the economy.

item.description: The pacts seek to establish a “preferential trade zone” that would counter China’s dominance in the sector.

item.title: Epstein Scandal Sees Ex-Prince Andrew Booted From Royal Lodge
item.description: The continued disclosures about the former duke’s relationship with Jeffrey Epstein have caused embarrassment to both the monarchy and Downing Street.

item.title: Why India Will Struggle to Reduce Its Reliance on Russian Oil
item.description: India relies on Russia for roughly a third of its oil imports, up from just 2% before Russia invaded Ukraine in early 2022.

item.title: America’s Critical-Minerals Strategy Looks Increasingly Chinese
item.description: The plan for the newly created U.S. Strategic Critical Minerals Reserve borrows from Beijing’s longstanding playbook.

item.title: Without Immigrants, U.K. Economy Would Be Smaller, More Indebted, Says NIESR

item.title: Former Fed Adviser Is Acquitted of Economic Espionage Conspiracy Charges
item.description: John Rogers was convicted of a lesser charge in a case that featured spycraft, online seduction and a blackmail scam.

item.title: U.S.-Iranian Talks Are Still Expected After Gulf Flare-Ups
item.description: The U.S. shot down an Iranian drone aimed at an aircraft carrier and Iranian gunboats tried to stop a U.S.-flagged ship.

item.title: After Months of Insults, Trump’s Meeting With Colombian President Ends in Detente
item.description: The U.S. president had branded Gustavo Petro “a lunatic” and criticized Colombia’s efforts to fight the drug trade before the two met at the White House.

item.title: Russia Resumes Strikes on Ukrainian Energy Sites
item.description: An attack hit thermal power plants across Ukraine after President Trump had asked Moscow to stand down as freezing temperatures gripped the region.

item.title: Three-Quarters of Greenlanders Don’t Want to Be Part of the U.S., Poll Shows

item.title: EU Launches In-Depth Foreign Subsidies Probe Into China’s Goldwind

item.title: Spain to Ban Access to Social Media for Children Under 16
item.description: The move would follow a decision taken by Australia last year, while Malaysia intends to place restrictions and New Zealand considers similar measures.

item.title: Venezuelans in Florida Are Torn Between Two Homes
item.description: Despite dreams of returning, “the longer you’ve been out of your country, the harder it will be,” says a Miami theater-company director who is a native of Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Arian Campo-Flores

item.title: Milei Hunts for Over $250 Billion That Argentines Have Hidden in Secret Stashes
item.description: The nation of cautious savers has long stowed U.S. dollars in teddy bears and safe-deposit boxes. The president now needs the money for his free-market overhaul.

item.description: The threat of China and U.S. weapons underpin the island’s reliance on Washington.

item.title: Epstein Scandal Sends Shockwaves Through the British Establishment

item.title: Gaza’s Border With Egypt Reopens, but Few Palestinians Make It Across

item.title: Costa Rica Elects a Conservative as Latin America Shifts to the Right

item.title: China Manufacturing Gauge Shows Pickup in Activity
item.description: A private gauge of China’s manufacturing sector showed factories continued to expand activity in January.

item.title: Venezuela’s New Leader Is Trying to Run Out the Clock on Trump

item.title: Trump Faces High-Stakes Choice as Final Nuclear Pact With Russia Expires
item.description: Moscow has proposed a de facto one-year extension of limits on long-range nuclear weapons after a strategic arms treaty lapses next week, but the president has yet to commit
item.dc:creator: Robbie Gramer

item.description: In a blow to China, the Supreme Court said CK Hutchison’s contract breaches the constitution.

item.description: The agreement is both economies’ largest and will link almost two billion consumers.

item.title: Several People Missing After Landslide Buries Campground in New Zealand
item.description: Debris engulfed the site at Mount Maunganui following record rainfall. A government minister said young people were among the missing.

item.title: Gilt Yields Rise, Sterling Falls as Political Uncertainty Resurfaces in U.K.

item.title: British American Tobacco to End South African Manufacturing
item.description: BAT South Africa said it would cease cigarette production in the country because of “the devastating impact of the illicit cigarette trade”.
